sourceDesc.p: This publication constitutes a remediation of the printed Inns of Court collection. Information on original sources for transcriptions can be accessed via the Document Descriptions.
For a full list of REED collections, editors, executive board members, and staff, please visit http://reed.utoronto.ca/people

prefixDef.p: Private URIs using the taxon prefix are pointers to entities in the taxonomy.xml file. For example, taxon:church dereferences to taxonomy.xml#church.
Private URIs using the gloss prefix are pointers to entities in the glossary.xml file. For example, gloss:histrio-1 dereferences to glossary.xml#histrio-1.

projectDesc.p: Records of Early English Drama (REED) is an international scholarly project that is establishing for the first time the context from which the drama of Shakespeare and his contemporaries grew. Founded in 1976, REED has worked since then to locate, transcribe, and edit historical documents containing evidence of drama, secular music, and other communal entertainment and ceremony from the Middle Ages until 1642, when the Puritans closed the London theatres.

row.cell: Ordinatum est ad hoc parliamentum quod festum Natalis Domini solempniter (non grande) celerabiturfor celebrabitur Et quod Communie continuabuntur vsque ad proximum Terminum et allocatur hic commorantibus vna biga Carbonum et quadraginta solidi pro salario Musicorum ante hac consueto, Et preteria allocatur pro Communijs

At this parliament it was ordered that the feast of Christmas will be celebrated solemnly, not grandly, and that commons will be continued up until next term; and one cart-load of coals is allowed for those remaining here and 40s for the musicians’ salary (as has been) previously customary, and in addition allowed for the commons

div.head: f 48v(21 February)
div.ab: Inigo Iones armiger admissus est in Societatem Medij Templi Specialiter ex assensu Roberti Davyes armigeri Modo Lectoris et aliorum Magistrorum de Banco
Inigo Jones, esquire, has been admitted specially into the society of the Middle Temple by the assent of Robert Davies, esquire, reader at present, and (by the assent) of other benchers.

note.ab: Inigo Iones’ (p 159, l.34): Jones’s special admission is also recorded on a loose sheet (see p 164).

div.head: f 54(11 June)
div.ab: A generall Taxacion fforasmvch as at this tyme the howse standeth indebted in dyvers somes of money amounting in the whole to the some of six hundred poundes and moore, wheareof a greate parte of the said some of six hundred poundes ys owing vnto dyvers artificers in this Cittye, such as are not able to forbeare their money but to their greate losse or vndoing, ffor avoyding of all such inconveniences which maye heereafter grow by reason of the said debt, The infra hic. b. Masters of the Bench have at this present parliament decreed and so ordered that there shalbe forthwith another taxacion presently levyed thorowgh owt this howse, videlicet everye one of the Masters of the Bench to paye iij li., and everye one of the Masters of the vtterbarr to paye xl s., and everye other gentleman of this ffellowshipp to paye xx s.
Provided that all such gentlemen of this howse that have bynn admytted since the first daye of Easter Tearme last, and all others to be admitted heereafter shalbe free from this tax./

note.ab: Although the taxation (p 160, l.4m) is not explicitly tied to the masque of this year, reference to ‘dyvers artificers in this Cittye’ (p 160, l.6) points unequivocally in that direction.

div.head: f 54v(16 June)
div.ab: Taxacion Whereas at the parliament holden the xjth daye of this instant moneth of Iune, Yt was then ordered by all the Masters of the Bench, that there showld be an other taxacion presently levyed thorowgh owt this howse videlicet every every one of the Masters of the Bench to paye iij li., and every one of the Masters of the vtterbarr to paye xl s., and every other gentleman of supra hic. a. this ffellowshipp to paye xx s., Synce which tyme the Masters of the Bench vnderstanding the vnwillingnes of the gentlemen to be taxed at such greate somes, and the saide Masters of the Bench willing to ease them as mvche as in them lyeth, have ordered that wheareas the Masters of the Bench weare taxed at iij li. a peece, to be now but l s. a peece which ys forth with to be payde, and everye vtterbarrister which was to paye xl s. ys now to paye but xxx s. the one half thereof to be payde before sundaye next,20 June 1613 and the other half to be payde before the ffeastdaye of all Saintes next comming, And every other gentlemen of this ffellowshipp which was, to paye xx s. a peece ys nowe to paye but xv s. the one half thereof to be payde before Sundaye next,20 June 1613 and the other half to be payde before the ffeastdaye of all Sayntes next commyng as aforesayde, and all gentlemen that are Attorneys or practisers of the house to paye xx s. a peece, the one half thereof to be payde before before Sundaye next20 June 1613 and the other half thereof to be paide before the feast of all Sayntes next commyng as aforesayde, And further wheareas dy..rs gentlemen of this ffellowshipp have vsually come into Commons in the vacacion tymes, and not in the Tearme tymes onelye to avoyde the payment of duetyes. Yt ys therefore further ordered that all such gentlemen that now are in Commones, or that shall come into Commons at anye tyme heereafter, shall not goe owt of Commons before they have payde all such some or somes by them due as aforesayde./

div.head: f 55(18 June)
div.ab: infra 67.b. Whereas Edward Powell gentlemen one of the ffellowes of this howse hathe of his voluntary mynde lent vnto the ffellowshipp of this howse the towardes the defraying of the chardg of the late Maske the some of fiftye poundes curraunt money, ffor repayment whereof the Masters of the Benche have at this present parliament with one consent decreed and so ordered that the Powell lent 50 li. saide some of fyftye poundes shalbe repayd vnto the saide Edward Powell his executors or assignes at the ende of six monethes next after the date of this present parliament./

div.head: f 55v
div.ab: Baldwines, Barkers, & Bluntes bond discharged And further wheareas Richard Baldwin, ffrauncis Barker, & Arthur Blunt, Officers of this howse at ye instance of the right worshipfull the Masters of the Bench of this howse, doe stand ioyntly and seuerally bound in one obligacion bearing date the xvth daye of ffebruary last past vnto Sir Thomas Temple of Stauntonbury in the Countye of Buckinghamshire knight in the some of fower hundred poundes of lawfull money of England, with condicion for the payment of two hundred and fifteene poundes one the xviijth daye of November next ensuing, as by the same obligacion and condicion more at large yt doth and maye appeare, which money was imployed towardes the defraying of the charge of the late maske, Now the Masters of the Bench have at this present parliament with one consent and agreement, decreed & soe ordered that the saide of somme of CCxv li. shalbe repayde vnto the sayde Sir Thomas Temple his executors or assignes one the saide xviijth daye of November and according to the tenor and effect of the sayde obligacion & condicion,

note.ab: The ‘late Maske’ (p 161, l.13) is Chapman’s Memorable Masque. Hopwood, Middle Temple Records, vol 2, pp 566–7, and Orbison (ed), Collections 12, pp 5, 23, misread the entry on f 55v (p 161) to say that the Temple lent £215, not £400.

row.cell: Ordinatum est ad hoc parliamentum quod ffestum Natalis domini solempniter (non grandeclosing parenthesis omitted celebrabitur, Et quod Communie continuabuntur vsque ad proximum Terminum et allocatur hic Commorantibus vna biga Carbonum et quadraginta solidi pro salario Musicorum ante hac consueto, Et preteria allocatur pro Communijs

It was ordered at this parliament that the feast of Christmas will be celebrated solemnly, not grandly, and that commons will be continued up until next term; and one cart-load of coals is allowed for those remaining here and 40s for the musicians’ salary (as has been) previously customary, and in addition allowed for the commons

div.head: f 66(28 January)
div.ab: Disinge, Cardinge, & Lords of Misrule Whereas dyvers actes of parliament of this howse have formerly bynn made videlicet 27o 33o et 34to Elizabeth against dising, carding, owtcrise in the night setting vp of ofdittography Lords of Misrule, breaking vpp of Chamber doores and other disorders, as in the said seuerall actes of parliament more at large ys specified, And wheareas mr Watson, mr Angell, mr Argent, and mr Spatchurst Iunior, have not withstanding the saide seuerall actes of Parliament and ordinances with others as yet to the Masters of the Bench vnknowne, contemptuously vppon the vijth daye of this instant moneth of Ianuary sett vpp the saide mr Watson for their Lord of Misrule, broken open Chamber doores as well within the howse as owt of the howse, made owtcrise in the night with striking vpp of drumes and blowing of hornes aswell within the howse as in the streetes and comytted other disorders., Yt ys therefore thowght fytt and so ordered by all the Masters of the Bench at this parliament that mr Watson and mr Angell shall paye for their offences to the Treasurer of this howse to the vse of this howse for their saide disorders the some of six poundes thirteene shillinges and fower pence a peece, and that the saide mr Argent shall paye for his offence the some of fyve poundes and Mr Spatchurst to paye for his offence in going abroade with the Lord of Misrule the some of infra 67.b. fyve markes, In which case they are onely fined and not expelled the howse, because as they pretend they knew not of the saide former statutes, And yf the saide seuerall somes be not payde before Mundaye night next,31 January 1613/14 that then they to be expulsed owt of this howse and fellowshipp/

note.ab: For the acts of parliament referenced in ll.21–4, see pp 118–19 and endnote, which is this ...

The order of 25 November, 27 Elizabeth (1584) (ll.3–4) occurs on f 171v, flagged in the margin, ‘Cardes dice & Candlemas Lorde:/’: It ys ordered yat none shall play at dice nor cardes with in this howse, neyther in the hall, nor in the chambers, at any tyme of the yeare, vppon payne to be expulsed the howse, And also yat no out cries in the night be made, nor chambers broken open by any gentlemen of this house, as by Lorde of Candlemas night or suche Lyke mysorder vppon payne of puttinge out of the hous commons for such offence This entry contains a marginal reference to a still earlier entry on f 150, dated 9 February 1583/4 and flagged by the marginal note ‘Dycesinge’: ‘And Likwise hit ys ordeyned that in the feaste of Christmas hensfourth no Dicesinge within this saide house be had and vsed, vppon payne of puttinge of such persone or persons out of Commons which shall practise the same.’ A similar entry, ff 207–7v, for 6 February 1589/90, concerns unspecified disorders which occurred four days earlier on ‘Candlemas night.’ Three of these entries are referenced in a much later entry, dated 28 January 1613/14 (see p 177).

div.head: f 67v(11 February)
div.ab: supra 66.a And further whereas at the first parliament of this Hillary Tearme, mr Watson, mr Angell, mr Argent, and mr Spatchurst Iunior weare fined, for dyvers Misdemeanors and disorders by them commytted this last Christmas, as by the sayde act of parliament yt dothe and maye appeare, more at large,/ Nowe Watson, Angell Argent & Spatchurst restored for asmvch as the sayde mr Watson, mr Angell mr Argent, and mr Spatchurst have at this parliament submitted themselves to the Masters of the Benche at th acknowledging their seuerall offencersfor offences in breaking of the Lawes and orders of this howse formerly made, The Masters of the Bench at this parliament by the Mediation of the right Worshipfull Sir Edward Phelipps knight Master of the Rolls, have accepted of their saide submissions, and therevppon pardoned all their fines, and restored them into this howse and fellowshipp and to their former antiquities, anye acte or order of this howse to the contrarye notwithstanding./
